city.name: Lisbon
city.about:
Lisbon is the capital of Portugal situated on seven hills at the wide mouth of the river Tagus where it meets the Atlantic Ocean. With 545,000 residents in the city and 3.0 million in the Lisbon Region (2024) and a thriving mix of Portugal's rich history and vivid contemporary culture, Lisbon enchants travellers with its white bleached limestone buildings, intimate alleyways, and an easy going charm that makes it a popular year round destination.
Greater Lisbon comprises many other splendid tourist destinations such as the of Sintra, the seaside resorts of Estoril, Cascais, the world class museums, or Almada famous for its hilltop Cristo Rei statue, all of which are connected with Lisbon by excellent public transportation links.

points_of_interest.name: Bar Trobadores
points_of_interest.description: Medieval bar in downtown with a cozy atmosphere and a diverse range of traditional Portuguese delicacies. National and international beers.

points_of_interest.name: Pastéis de Belém
points_of_interest.description: Antiga Confeitaria de Belém The most famous of pastelarias, and justly so. They are served right out of the oven there, with the side of confectioner's sugar and cinnamon. As you navigate through the tile-covered labyrinthine passages of the expansive shop, stop to look at the workers behind glass panels turning the endless stream of these delicacies, just baked, each in its own little ramekin, over onto the waiting trays. These are absolutely a must-eat and you can't possibly regret it.

points_of_interest.name: Café Martinho da Arcada
points_of_interest.description: Established in 1782, this is the oldest continuously-operating café in Lisbon and throughout its history has been associated with important politicians, writers, and intellectuals. Writer Fernando Pessoa had a permanent table reservation, as did the late Nobel laureate José Saramago.

points_of_interest.name: Lux Fragil
points_of_interest.description: It's in a former warehouse and part owned by American actor John Malkovich.
points_of_interest.address: Av. Infante D. Henrique, Armazém A

points_of_interest.name: Pois Café
points_of_interest.description: It's a place to relax, read a book, drink a coffee and plan your way around Lisbon. Also offers toasts, pastas, quiches and salads; features late breakfasts.

points_of_interest.name: Portas do Sol
points_of_interest.description: A cafe and bar on a "Miradouro", viewing spot, and thus offer a spectacular view over the Alfama rooftops down to the river.

points_of_interest.name: Café A Brasileira
points_of_interest.description: One of Lisbon's remaining classic cafés, with a restaurant in the basement; despite renovation, not much has changed since the 1920s. The café was Fernando Pessoa's favourite place, and a statue of the poet/philosopher stands outside the main entrance on the terrace.

points_of_interest.name: Manteigaria - Fábrica de Pastéis de Nata
points_of_interest.description: A bakery serving some of the best ''pastéis de nata'' in town, arguably the best in Lisbon. You can even watch them make the pasteis de nata. Standing room only.

points_of_interest.name: Chafariz do Vinho
points_of_interest.description: Perfect place to linger over a glass of wine at this wine bar that is under the arches of the city's former acquaducts. With a great selection of appetizers that are matched perfectly with the wine, it's a pleasant way to spend an evening.

points_of_interest.name: Garrafeira Alfaia
points_of_interest.description: Nice wine bar with an impressive selection of good wines and appetizers. Good place to spend the late afternoon, before going out to dinner.

points_of_interest.name: Tivoli Hotel Sky Bar
points_of_interest.description: The superbly located rooftop bar of Tivoli Hotel is a small secret. On warm evenings one of the best places to have an overpriced late drink. Youngish music late night.

points_of_interest.name: Fado In Chiado
points_of_interest.description: Fado In Chiado - Daily show (except on Sundays) at 19:00, with a duration of 50 minutes. Voices that sing the Fado to the sound of Portuguese guitar.

points_of_interest.name: Tasca do Chico
points_of_interest.description: A cramped but authentic Fado bar.

points_of_interest.name: A Avó Tinha
points_of_interest.description: A modern take on traditional Portuguese dishes.

points_of_interest.name: O Cubo
points_of_interest.description: A place for a family meal or a business lunch.
points_of_interest.address: Rua Dom Francisco Manuel de Melo 16B

points_of_interest.name: D'Bacalhau
points_of_interest.description: Specializing in cod, they also serve steaks and other fish. It's along the river with nice views from the upstairs dining room.

points_of_interest.name: Eleven
points_of_interest.description: Michelin-starred restaurant in Jardim Amália Rodrigues with views of Parque Eduardo VII.

points_of_interest.name: Fifty Seconds
points_of_interest.description: Michelin-starred restaurant by Spanish chef Martín Berasategui, in the Myriad Sana Hotel {{m|120}} up the Vasco da Gama Tower, offering spectacular views.

points_of_interest.name: Fábrica Imperial
points_of_interest.description: They say they serve grandma's cooking with the love of a grandchild.

points_of_interest.name: Oásis Vegetariano
points_of_interest.description: Vegetarian and vegan dishes.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Santa Rita
points_of_interest.description: Authentic, cheap Portuguese dishes in a very busy, shared-table restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: Il Gattopardo
points_of_interest.description: An elegant restaurant serving fashionable gourmet Italian.

points_of_interest.name: Páteo Restaurante
points_of_interest.description: Traditional Portuguese cuisine.
points_of_interest.address: Edifício Adamastor, Avenida Dom João II 11B

points_of_interest.name: Leitaria Camponeza
points_of_interest.description: On the location of a historical café (the ''leitaria''), this place focuses on only a short number of dishes (meats, fish and seafood) but makes up for this in quality and portion size. For an atmospheric presentation ask for one of their ''espetadas''. The wines complement the dishes and you can end the meal with a dessert. For someone looking for great value for their buck (no compromises on quality), it's a good place to start or end an evening.

points_of_interest.name: Velha Gaiteira
points_of_interest.description: A charming spot with a welcoming host. A delicious prix fixe meal was €12.50.

points_of_interest.name: Mercado da Praça da Figueira
points_of_interest.description: From the pavement looks like a small convenience shop, on walking in you realize the deception when confronted by the large cavernous meandering interior space, replete with everything expected from a well stocked supermarket. Although there isn't a restaurant as such, the ready to eat items on offer are tasty, fresh, inexpensive and varied. The sandwiches and hamburgers are superb.

points_of_interest.name: Eneko Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Michelin-starred restaurant by Spanish Basque chef Eneko Atxa. Attached to a more laid-back space called "Basque".

points_of_interest.name: Mercado Oriental
points_of_interest.description: Supermercado Oriental - Amanhecer A food court serving Asian street food and the only place in Lisbon where you can try Macanese cuisine (at a stall called "Taberna Macau").

points_of_interest.name: Feitoria
points_of_interest.description: Michelin-starred seafood restaurant by the docks.

points_of_interest.name: Néctar WineBar
points_of_interest.description: A place dedicated to the promotion of Portugal's wine and gastronomic culture, and featuring a daily lunch menu of Portuguese and Mediterranean cuisine. The wine list comprises – in its vast majority – a selection of Portuguese wines which best represent the country. Wine can be bought by the glass, and it is served at the appropriate temperatures and in suitable glasses. Dishes – served in portions for 2 – easily replace a main course meal. Homemade-style desserts, for which sweet wines can be suggested. A modern and cosy atmosphere.

points_of_interest.name: A Marítima do Restelo
points_of_interest.description: Seafood restaurant by the water.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Bonjardim
points_of_interest.description: Appropriately nicknamed ''Rei dos Frangos'', this is home to the best greasy spit-roasted chicken this side of Louisiana.

points_of_interest.name: Prova - Enoteca
points_of_interest.description: Modern, urban wine bar serving seafood and sausage & cheese platters in a convivial atmosphere.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Gambrinus
points_of_interest.description: A restaurant-bar which is one of the most chic places in the city. Highly recognized in Lisbon as something of an institution, it attracts an eclectic crowd where the appeal is food and a great selection of beers, wines and spirits. Features smoking room, private parking with a doorman.
points_of_interest.address: Rua das Portas de Santo Antao, 23

points_of_interest.name: Chapitô à Mesa
points_of_interest.description: Great views are the main feature if you reserve terrace seat in advance. Good atmosphere; international-menu food is tasty but nothing special.

points_of_interest.name: Taberna dos Ferreiros
points_of_interest.description: A fresh take on Mediterranean cuisine.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Tascardoso
points_of_interest.sub_category: Around the Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara
points_of_interest.description: Standing-room only, this place serves simple and affordable Portuguese dishes, including grilled sardines. Toilets available.

points_of_interest.name: Farol de Santa Luzia
points_of_interest.description: Great place to have typical Portuguese food before climbing to Castelo S. Jorge.

points_of_interest.name: 11 Tapas - Restaurante & Cocktail, WineBar
points_of_interest.sub_category: Around the Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara

points_of_interest.name: Malmequer Bemmequer
points_of_interest.description: Friendly and inexpensive; long menu of traditional Portuguese dishes.

points_of_interest.name: Taberna Minhota
points_of_interest.sub_category: Around the Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara
points_of_interest.description: A tapas restaurant
points_of_interest.address: R. de São Pedro de Alcântara 13

points_of_interest.name: Mestiço
points_of_interest.description: What used to be a Nepalese curry house is now a very friendly African eatery with authentic food. In the evening musicians play for an even more atmospheric setting.

points_of_interest.name: Sabores na Travessa
points_of_interest.sub_category: Around the Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara

points_of_interest.name: Portuel Kosher Store
points_of_interest.description: Lisbon's source for kosher groceries.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Cantinho da Rosa
points_of_interest.sub_category: Around the Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara

points_of_interest.name: Zambeze
points_of_interest.description: A Mozambique restaurant on a "miradouro", viewing spot, offering a great view of the river, the Baixa area, and beyond. An elevator can bring you up and down the deep slopes, making it easily reachable from the nearby Baixa area.

points_of_interest.name: Hawaii Poke-In
points_of_interest.sub_category: Around the Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara

points_of_interest.name: Lusitânia Tony
points_of_interest.sub_category: Around the Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara

points_of_interest.name: A Cabana da Estrela
points_of_interest.address: R. da Bela Vista à Lapa 20

points_of_interest.name: Time Out Market
points_of_interest.description: Mercado da Ribeira The late 19th-century market was closed in 2000, and in 2014 the publisher ''Time Out Portugal'' transformed the space into a gourmet food court with 40 kiosks, including restaurants, bars, and shops. A number of Lisbon's top chefs have stands here, making this an ideal place to sample some of their food for lower prices than at their established restaurants.

points_of_interest.name: Rosa da Rua Restaurante
points_of_interest.description: A traditional restaurant offering an interesting mix of Portuguese, Indian, and Cape Verdean flavours. The lunch-time buffet offers excellent value for money and great quality food. Staff are patient with English speakers.

points_of_interest.name: Faca & Garfo
points_of_interest.description: A cozy and affordable restaurant which offers tasty grilled Portuguese specialities of meat and fish.

points_of_interest.name: Bengal Tandoori
points_of_interest.description: Cuisine of East Bengal, India, using a tandoor oven.

points_of_interest.name: Cervejaria da Trindade
points_of_interest.description: This excellent restaurant-brewery in a former monastery has several kinds of Sagres beer and Guinness. The appetizer that is charged for each item that is consumed separately. Nice codfish plates.

points_of_interest.name: Os Tibetanos
points_of_interest.description: Vegetarian restaurant affiliated with a Buddhist center. Vegan friendly. Juice bar.

points_of_interest.name: Tamarind
points_of_interest.description: Small Indian restaurant. Reservations can be made online.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Brasuca
points_of_interest.description: Great Brazilian food served by friendly staff.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Calcutá 2
points_of_interest.description: The second of two restaurants operated by the same owners. Decent Indian food, but far from the best. The location is great though for starting a night out on the town. Ask for the shoot drinks!

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Lisboa À Noite
points_of_interest.description: A restaurant with a variety of traditional Portuguese dishes very appreciated by the tourists. Friendly environment, great service. Make sure you try the appetizers.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Sacramento do Chiado
points_of_interest.description: A popular locals' place in palace stables from the 18th-century . The atmosphere and the food are excellent. Service is very good and the recommendations by the staff are outstanding. The writing on the menu is very small and difficult to read in the subdued lighting.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Sinal Vermelho
points_of_interest.description: Good traditional Portuguese at reasonable prices.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurante Terra
points_of_interest.description: Probably the best vegetarian restaurant in Lisbon and also the nicest in terms of ambience and service. They have a menu in English and will help with vegan choices or people with other dietary restrictions. Reservations are recommended, especially on weekends but you will always be served even if you arrive with the place full and have to wait for a while. Weather permitting try to get a table outside, which means a wonderful and secluded back terrace.

points_of_interest.name: Come Prima
points_of_interest.description: Traditional Italian fresh pasta dishes, various starters, risottos, meats and wood-oven pizzas are produced from a wide selection of prime quality fresh ingredients. Extensive wine list procured from both national and Italian producers and a delightful choice of desserts carefully picked from the Italian classics.

points_of_interest.name: Café Buenos Aires
points_of_interest.description: A good and selected combination of cheap and mid range dishes. The owners are very friendly and speak English, as well as Portuguese. It is a good restaurant if you want to eat South American grilled meat.

points_of_interest.name: Belcanto
points_of_interest.description: Contemporary Portuguese cuisine with two Michelin stars.

points_of_interest.name: Alma
points_of_interest.description: Two-Michelin-star fine dining by chef Henrique Sá Pessoa, blending traditional Portuguese cuisine with Asian influences. Choose from two tasting menus or order à la carte.

points_of_interest.name: Loco Restaurante
points_of_interest.description: Michelin-starred restaurant offering two tasting menus using local ingredients by chef Alexandre Silva, who won the first series of ''Top Chef de Portugal''.

points_of_interest.name: 100 Maneiras
points_of_interest.description: Michelin-starred restaurant by Bosnian chef Ljubomir Stanisic, who blends influences from his homeland, his adopted country, and elsewhere around the globe.

points_of_interest.name: Epur
points_of_interest.description: Michelin-starred restaurant by French chef Vincent Farges, who prepares an edgy surprise menu centred on visual elegance and purity of flavours.
points_of_interest.address: Largo da Academia Nacional de Belas Artes 14

points_of_interest.name: Moda Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Lisbon Fashion Week.

points_of_interest.name: Altice Arena
points_of_interest.description: formerly MEO Arena, originally Pavilhão Atlântico This 20,000-seat arena hosts touring rock bands and Brazilian musicians.

points_of_interest.name: Gulbenkian Music
points_of_interest.description: The Gulbenkian Foundation has its own symphony orchestra and ballet group. There are also two stages operated by the foundation. One major auditorium inside the main building, and an outdoors stage in the nearby Gulbenkian Gardens.

points_of_interest.name: Casino Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Among the gambling opportunities here are slot machines, poker, roulette, black jack, and baccarat. They have two restaurants, four bars, two entertainment venues, and an art gallery.

points_of_interest.name: Monsanto Forest Park
points_of_interest.description: Parque Florestal de Monsanto A municipal protected forest, the largest green patch in the city, covering almost 10 km². It offers a well-diversified, tree-covered area. 50 ha is set aside as the Ecological Park, which runs an interpretation centre, with space for permanent and occasional exhibitions, and a Centre of Multimedia Resources.
points_of_interest.address: Pista Cruz Das Oliveiras, 1500-389 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Teatro Nacional Dona Maria II
points_of_interest.description: Queen Maria II National Theatre The most famous live theatre stage in Lisbon. The Neoclassical and Palladian building was built in the 1840s and has been a national monument since 2003.

points_of_interest.name: Coliseu dos Recreios
points_of_interest.description: Large multi-purpose auditorium for musical performances.
points_of_interest.address: Rua das Portas de Santo Antão 96

points_of_interest.name: Lisboa em Fado
points_of_interest.description: Fado in Lisbon A typical Portuguese Fado concert hall with daily evening shows. Run by a young Fado guitarist from Lisbon. The show lasts about one hour.

points_of_interest.name: Teatro Maria Vitória
points_of_interest.description: Presenting ''teatro de revista'', Portuguese-style comedy revues. The theatre opened in 1922 and was restored in 1990 following a 1986 fire.

points_of_interest.name: Quake - Lisbon Earthquake Centre
points_of_interest.description: Quake - Centro do Terramoto de Lisboa A fully interactive museum on the Lisbon Earthquake of 1755.

points_of_interest.name: Igreja do Carmo
points_of_interest.description: The hilltop church of the former convent of Carmo is a towering memorial of the 1755 earthquake, which made the roof of the church collapse, but the Gothic arches of the nave survived. The church was preserved that way and now serves as the '''Museu Arqueológico''' in the extant parts of the building. The museum houses a hodgepodge of archaeological artifacts from around Portugal and the world including mummies from South America, tombs of Portuguese rulers, and the Stations of the Cross on 18th-century painted tiles. The assorted artifacts are not well explained, but the church is a sight to see and visitors come to relax in the grassy nave of the church, and draw or photograph the spires.
points_of_interest.hours: Oct-May: M-Sa 10:00-18:00; Jun-Sep: M-Sa 10:00-19:00; closed Su, 1 Jan, 1 May, 25 Dec

points_of_interest.name: Feira Internacional de Lisboa
points_of_interest.description:
The Feira Internacional de Lisboa, also known as Expo '98, was a World's Fair held in Lisbon, Portugal. The theme "The Oceans, a Heritage for the Future" commemorated 500 years of Portuguese discoveries. 

It attracted over 10 million visitors and featured 143 countries and various organizations.

points_of_interest.name: MUDE – Museu do Design e da Moda
points_of_interest.description: Museum of Design and Fashion The collection has about 1,000 items of furniture and accessories and over 1,200 pieces of haute couture clothing.
points_of_interest.hours: Temporarily closed for renovations; planned reopening 2023

points_of_interest.name: Miradouro de Santa Luzia
points_of_interest.description: Good viewpoint in Alfama uphill from the cathedral along tram route. Lovely view over rooftops and river.

points_of_interest.name: Ajuda Botanical Gardens
points_of_interest.description: Jardim Botânico da Ajuda The botanical garden of Ajuda is one of the oldest gardens in Europe and is considered the first in Portugal. After the earthquake that occurred in 1755, the homeless Portuguese royal family decided to build a new royal residence at Ajuda but also gardens around it. This 10-acre garden was laid out in from 1858-1873.

points_of_interest.name: Calouste Gulbenkian Museum
points_of_interest.description: One of the best museums in Lisbon. Created from the personal collection of the art and artifact collector Calouste Gulbenkian. The collection include Egyptian artefacts; Islamic and oriental art; paintings by masters such as Rembrandt, Manet, Monet, Renoir, and Cassat; and a large collection of objects made by the Art Nouveau jeweler René Lalique. Gulbenkian was an Armenian born in the Ottoman Empire who, through his investments in Iraqi oil, became one of the wealthiest men of his time. During a journey he fell ill and had to seek medical attention in Lisbon. He fell in love with the city and decided live out his final days there. After his death his immense collections were organized into this museum. The ''[https://gulbenkian.pt/jardim/en/ Gulbenkian Gardens]'' which surround the museums and foundation building are worth a visit in and of themselves, as a little oasis in the middle of downtown Lisbon. They're free and open sunrise to sunset.

points_of_interest.name: Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara
points_of_interest.description:
Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara offers a stunning panorama from its lovely garden. Located on top of the Elevador da Glória, it provides breathtaking views. 

This picturesque spot is situated near the northern corner of Bairro Alto, making it a great place to take in the sights.

points_of_interest.name: Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Conceição Velha
points_of_interest.description: Old Church of Our Lady of the Conception 18th-century Manueline-style church, a national monument.

points_of_interest.name: Castelo de São Jorge
points_of_interest.description: St. George's Castle Humans settled on this hill as early as the 8th century BCE, and the first fortifications date from the 1st century BCE. Before the Portuguese conquest in the 1147 Siege of Lisbon, the site was successively occupied by the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans, and Moors. Sights within the castle include the permanent exhibition of archaeological artefacts with an emphasis on the 11th- and 12th-century Moors, ruins of the former Royal Palace of Alcáçova, a garden with native forest species, and a camera obscura showing the city's sights. The castle offers great view over the city and the river. If you have the energy, get there by walking from downtown, going through the fantastic old neighbourhood of Alfama.

points_of_interest.name: Centro Cultural de Belém
points_of_interest.description: CCB, Belém Cultural Center CCB is a {{m2|140000}} complex of artistic and cultural venues. It has spaces for meetings and conferences, performing arts (film, opera, ballet, theatre, and music), and art exhibits (art, architecture, design, and photography).

points_of_interest.name: Centro de Arte Moderna
points_of_interest.description: Modern Art Centre A museum dedicated to art since the 1950s, focusing on Portuguese artists and including other nationalities, notably British and Armenian. Part of the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation.
points_of_interest.hours: Daily 10:00 – 18:00, closed on Tuesdays, 10:00 – 21:00 on Saturdays

points_of_interest.name: Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga
points_of_interest.description: Portugal's impressive national art collection, including 14-19th century European painting, artefacts of Portuguese contact with the East and Africa and a collection of ecclesiastical treasures. Highlights include Dürer's St Jerome, Hieronymus Bosch's Temptations of St Antony, Nuno Gonçalves' Adoration of St Vincent, and 16th century Japanese paintings of Portuguese traders.

points_of_interest.name: Palácio Alverca
points_of_interest.description: Antigo Palácio Pais do Amaral, Antigo Palácio São Luís, Casa do Alentejo Unassuming from the outside, the interior combines neo-Gothic, neo-Arab, neo-Renaissance, neo-Rococo, Art Nouveau, and baroque elements.

points_of_interest.name: Monument to the Discoveries
points_of_interest.description: Padrão dos Descobrimentos Climbing the monument gives you a spectacular view of Belém.
points_of_interest.address: Avenida De Brasília, 1300-598 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Jardim Zoológico
points_of_interest.description:
Jardim Zoológico is a popular zoo featuring a variety of animals in naturalistic enclosures. 
With thousands of zoos worldwide, it stands out as a must-visit destination, attracting millions of visitors each year.

points_of_interest.name: Museu da Marioneta
points_of_interest.description: Puppetry Museum The museum covers the history of puppetry around the world, with an emphasis on Portugal. Various types of puppets are on display.
points_of_interest.address: Convento das Bernardas, Rua da Esperança 146

points_of_interest.name: Pavilhão do Conhecimento - Centro Ciência Viva
points_of_interest.description: Pavilion of Knowledge - Living Science Centre Ciência Viva is an interactive science and technology museum that aims to make science accessible to all, stimulating experimentation and exploration of the physical world.

points_of_interest.name: Palácio Foz
points_of_interest.description: A palace constructed in the 18th and 19th centuries. Visits can be arranged in advance via email. Concerts (some of them free) are offered.

points_of_interest.name: Lisbon Cathedral
points_of_interest.description: Sé de Lisboa, Igreja de Santa Maria Maior Built in 1147, the cathedral has survived various earthquakes and has undergone restoration, renovation, and modification over the years. Its elements include Romanesque, Gothic, and Baroque styles. It has been a national monument since 1910.

points_of_interest.name: Mosteiro dos Jerónimos
points_of_interest.description: Jerónimos Monastery A {{UNESCO}}, the monastery was built in the 16th century and is an outstanding example of the Portuguese late Gothic Manueline style.
points_of_interest.hours: Oct-May: Tu-Su 10:00-17:30; May-Sep: Tu-Su 10:00-18:30; last entry 30 min before closing; closed 1 Jan, Easter, 1 May, 13 Jun, and 25 Dec

points_of_interest.name: Basílica da Estrela
points_of_interest.description: This Neoclassical and Baroque basilica, dedicated to the Sacred Heart of Jesus, was built in the late 1700s by Queen Maria I in fulfilment of a vow. The Queen is entombed in the right transept. Among the artworks is a nativity scene made up of over 500 cork and terracotta figures by Joaquim Machado de Castro.

points_of_interest.name: Praça do Comércio
points_of_interest.description: This magnificent plaza, facing the river, is the beginning of Lisboa's downtown. It is also known as 'Terreiro do Paço', meaning 'Grounds of the Palace', relating to its function before the Great Earthquake of 1755. The upper floors of the yellow buildings surrounding the square are mainly used as government offices, while the lower floors often contains cafés and restaurants. King Josef I, who ruled during the reconstruction of Lisbon, is seen as a mounted statue in the middle of the square, while the arch facing north is a tribute to the explorer Vasco da Gama.
points_of_interest.address: Praça Do Comércio 72, 1100-148 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Museu da Água
points_of_interest.description: This museum showcases the city's water supply infrastructure. The Museu da Água offers a unique glimpse into Lisbon's history and development.

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology
points_of_interest.description: MAAT – Museu de Arte, Arquitetura e Tecnologia This museum of contemporary art is housed in a riverside building of contemporary design.
points_of_interest.hours: W–M 11:00–19:00 (Jun–Sep: F Sa until 22:00), closed Tu

points_of_interest.name: Praça Marquês de Pombal
points_of_interest.description: Essentially a large roundabout with a sizeable statue of a former Portuguese prime minister in the middle.
points_of_interest.address: Túnel Do Marquês, 1250-161 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Museu Nacional do Azulejo
points_of_interest.description: National Tile Museum One of the most important national museums, dedicated to Portuguese ''azulejo'' tiles since the late 1400s. It's in the former Madre de Deus Convent, founded in 1509 by Queen Leonor.

points_of_interest.name: Museu Colecção Berardo
points_of_interest.description: The permanent collection of the museum consists of the Berardo Collection, which is made up of modern and contemporary art, with major art movements like abstract expressionism, Abstraction-Création, action painting, body Art, constructivism, cubism, De Stijl, digital art, experimental art, geometric abstraction, kinetic art, minimal art, neo-expressionism, neo-plasticism, neo-Realism, op art, photography, photorealism, pop art, realism, suprematism, surrealism. Includes artists like Piet Mondrian, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Pablo Picasso and Jackson Pollock, and Francis Bacon.

points_of_interest.name: Museu Militar de Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Lisbon Military Museum Housed in a 16th-century foundry, this museum holds its testaments to Portuguese military history, and contains many artifacts, including a sword used by Vasco da Gama.

points_of_interest.name: Museu da Marinha
points_of_interest.description: Navy Museum One of the most important in Europe, evoking Portugal's domination of the seas. Its colossal 17,000 items are installed in the west wing of Jerónimos Monastery, and include model ships from the Age of Discovery onward. The oldest exhibit is a wooden figure representing the Archangel Raphael that accompanied Vasco da Gama on his voyage to India.

points_of_interest.name: Cemitério dos Prazeres
points_of_interest.description: This large cemetery is packed with majestic gravestones and mausoleums, separated by wide, pedestrian, tree-lined "streets". Many graves are marked with icons telling something about the person's role in historical Lisbon. A beautiful respite from the busy city.

points_of_interest.name: Museu de Sociedade de Geografia
points_of_interest.description: Museu Etnográfico da Sociedade de Geografia de Lisboa Exhibits of ethnography from Portugal's former colonies.
points_of_interest.address: Rua das Portas de Santo Antão 100

points_of_interest.name: Museu Nacional dos Coches
points_of_interest.description: National Coach Museum Housed in the former riding school of the palace, don't miss the world's largest collection of horse-drawn coaches and other royal vehicles. One of Lisbon's many unusual museums. In the "Museum street", Belem.

points_of_interest.name: Fundação Arpad Szenes / Vieira da Silva
points_of_interest.description: This museum is installed in the restored 18th-century former Royal Silk Factory. Its permanent collection covers a wide time period of the works of 20th-century painters Arpad Szenes and Maria Helena Vieira da Silva, and regularly hosts exhibits by their contemporaries.

points_of_interest.name: Rossio Station
points_of_interest.description: Built in 1890 as the Estação Central (Central Station), it was the main railway hub until 1957. It provides a direct connection to Sintra in about 40 min. The trains access the station through a 2.6-km long tunnel. The main facade is an example of the Neo-Manueline style, a revival of Gothic style in Portugal during the mid-19th century.
points_of_interest.address: Praça Dos Restauradores 24, 1250-187 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Museu do Teatro Romano
points_of_interest.description: Roman Theatre Museum Along the way from downtown to Saint George's Castle.
points_of_interest.address: Rua de São Mamede, nº 3 A

points_of_interest.name: Planetário Calouste Gulbenkian
points_of_interest.description: Calouste Gulbenkian Planetarium The planetarium has 32 star projectors, capable of presenting more than 9,000 stars. It holds a chunk of moon rock given by U.S. President Richard Nixon.
points_of_interest.hours: Temporarily closed for renovations; planned reopening Oct 2021

points_of_interest.name: Aqueduto das Aguas Livres
points_of_interest.description: This is a historic aqueduct in the city of Lisbon, Portugal. It is one of the most remarkable examples of 18th-century Portuguese engineering, including the largest stone arch in the world. The main course of the aqueduct covers 18 km, but the whole network of canals extends through nearly 58 km. The Mãe d'Água (Mother of the Water) reservoir of the Amoreiras, the largest of the water reservoirs, was finished in 1834. This reservoir, with a capacity of 5,500 m³ of water, was designed by Carlos Mardel. It is now deactivated and can be visited as part of the Museu da Água (Water Museum).
points_of_interest.address: Rua Gorgel Do Amaral 4, 1250-259 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Santa Justa Lift {{rint|lisbon|54e}}
points_of_interest.description: Excellent vertical view of the Baixa streets, next to Igreja do Carmo. The line can be quite long, you may want to consider walking up and riding it down instead.
points_of_interest.address: Largo do Carmo - Rua do Ouro

points_of_interest.name: Panteão Nacional
points_of_interest.description: Igreja do Santa Engrácia This is one of the most striking buildings in Lisbon. Its tall dome and white facade makes it a real landmark in Alfama/Eastern Lisbon. Excellent views from the rooftop terrace. Construction began in 1681, then halted until the dome was added in 1966 and then converted to the National Pantheon. Amália Rodrigues, queen of fado, is buried here, and fresh roses can be seen on the tomb. The church also has wide viewing platform on the rooftop all around its dome. Excellent panorama of the river and surroundings. No elevator.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-Su 10:00-17:00, platform 10:00-18:00 (closed Mondays, shorter hours in winter)

points_of_interest.name: Ponte 25 de Abril
points_of_interest.description: This sister bridge of the San Francisco – Oakland Bay Bridge was designed by the same architect in 1966 to connect Lisbon with the Setubal peninsula across the Tagus (Tejo) River. Formerly known as the Salazar Bridge, it was renamed after the Carnation Revolution which, on 25 April 1974, ended the dictatorship.

points_of_interest.name: Espaço Novo Banco
points_of_interest.description:
The Espaço Novo Banco is located in a historic building that dates back to the Estado Novo era, a time of significant cultural and economic change in Portugal. 
Today, visitors can explore the Espaço Novo Banco and learn about this fascinating period in Portuguese history.

points_of_interest.name: Statue to Afonso de Albuquerque
points_of_interest.description: In front of the former Royal Palace of Belém, now the Presidential Palace, there is a massive statue looking out to sea, representing Afonso de Albuquerque, second ruler of Portuguese India in the early 16th century.
points_of_interest.address: Praça Afonso De Albuquerque 15, 1300-995 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Lisbon Botanical Gardens
points_of_interest.description: Jardim Botânico A hidden gem. It was created several hundred years ago, by a King of Portugal at the time of the Discoveries. The story goes that this King wanted one of every type of plant in the world, and although that's unlikely, there is a huge collection dating back by three or four centuries which is worth checking out. And there's something quite eerie about seeing plants or huge trees from completely different climates growing next to each other in apparent harmony. A great place to take a picnic: this green oasis is completely surrounded by city but even the city sounds filter out.

points_of_interest.name: Torre de Belém
points_of_interest.description:
The Torre de Belém is a 16th-century fortification in Lisbon that showcases Portugal's maritime power. 
It features a mix of architectural styles, including Manueline and Moorish influences. 
The tower is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a symbol of Europe's Age of Discoveries.
points_of_interest.hours: Oct-May: Tu-Su 10:00-17:30; May-Sep: Tu-Su 10:00-18:30; last entry 30 min before closing; closed 1 Jan, Easter, 1 May, 13 Jun, and 25 Dec

points_of_interest.name: Centro Colombo
points_of_interest.description: One of the largest malls in Europe, this shopping and leisure complex also houses dozens of restaurants, a bowling alley, health club and a multiplex cinema.

points_of_interest.name: El Corte Inglés
points_of_interest.description: The Spanish department store chain invaded Lisbon, armed with cinema and supermarket. It can be a bit pricey but with good quality items.

points_of_interest.name: Feira da Ladra
points_of_interest.description: A lively outdoor market offering new and used products. Markets of this type have pleased bargain hunters since the 12th century in Lisbon and the Feira da Ladra name has been around since the 17th century.

points_of_interest.name: Chocolataria Equador
points_of_interest.description: Chocolates, truffles, and barks that are as beautiful as they are delicious. Try the hot chocolate, served elegantly with a chocolate covered cherry.

points_of_interest.name: Armazéns do Chiado
points_of_interest.description: This upscale and trendy shopping centre was developed inside Lisbon's historic grand department store which burnt down in 1988. The food court on the top floor has a terrace with a brilliant view over Baixa and Chiado.

points_of_interest.name: Centro Comercial Amoreiras
points_of_interest.description: The city's oldest mall in eye-catching post-modern towers housing international chains.

points_of_interest.name: Mercado de Campo de Ourique
points_of_interest.description: An indoor market selling wide selection of fruits, vegetables, meats, fish, and jewelry. A perfect break while Tram 28 turns around, it's calmer and less crowded than other markets listed.

points_of_interest.name: A Vida Portuguesa
points_of_interest.description: Vintage and nostalgic products and brands.

points_of_interest.name: Livraria Bertrand
points_of_interest.description: Founded in 1732, it is the oldest operating bookstore in the world. If you want they can stamp the books you buy, certifying that they were bought there. While most books are in Portuguese there is a full shelf of English language literature, including many notable Portuguese titles translated to English. There's a small coffee-shop/bar area at the back of the shop with very helpful staff.

points_of_interest.name: Caza das Vellas Loreto
points_of_interest.description: A shop that has been selling beautiful homemade candles since 1789.

points_of_interest.name: America Diamonds Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Three-star, 66-room hotel, totally reconstructed in 2006 in a historical building, keeping only its original façade, contrasting with its modern interior. Amenities include bar, restaurant, room service, free breakfast, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: HI Parque das Nações Youth Hostel
points_of_interest.description: Pousada de Juventude 18-room youth hostel with free breakfast and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Four Seasons Hotel Ritz Lisbon
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 282-room hotel with spa, gym, swimming pool, restaurant, and bar. The decor is a mix of Art Deco and Louis XVI, with a collection of mid-20th-century Portuguese art.

points_of_interest.name: Ibis Lisboa Parque das Nações Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Three-star, 112-room hotel with bar, gym, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: HI Lisboa – Pousada de Juventude
points_of_interest.description: Youth Hostel 32-room youth hostel with free breakfast and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Myriad
points_of_interest.description: by Sana Hotels Five-star, 186-room hotel at the Vasco da Gama Tower offering panoramic river views. Amenities include indoor pool, spa, gym, restaurant, and bar.

points_of_interest.name: Intercontinental Lisbon Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 331-room hotel overlooking Parque Eduardo VII. Amenities include fitness centre, bar, business centre, conference facilities, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Olissippo Oriente
points_of_interest.description: Four-star, 182-room hotel with bar, conference facilities, business centre, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Lisbon Marriott Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Four-star, 577-room hotel with swimming pool, gym, bar, conference facilities, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Tivoli Oriente Lisboa Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Four-star, 279-room hotel with swimming pool, gym, restaurant, bar, and conference facilities.

points_of_interest.name: Novotel Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Four-star, 249-room hotel with swimming pool, gym, bar, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Meliá Lisboa Oriente
points_of_interest.description: Four-star, 207-room hotel with restaurant, bar, conference facilities, concierge, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Sheraton Lisboa Hotel & Spa
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 369-room hotel with swimming pool, spa, gym, business centre, and free Wi-Fi. Its rooftop '''Panorama Restaurant and Bar''' offers superb views over Lisbon.

points_of_interest.name: Altis Belem Hotel & Spa
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 50-room hotel overlooking the Tagus with pool, spa, gym, bar, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Beira Minho
points_of_interest.description: A great location, but with few amenities.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Jerónimos 8
points_of_interest.description: Four-star, 65-room hotel with bar, sauna, free breakfast, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Bom Conforto Casa de Hospedes
points_of_interest.description: Very clean, quiet, and comfortable. Helpful and sweet English-speaking staff.

points_of_interest.name: Nau Palácio do Governador
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 60 room hotel with spa, gym, two swimming pools, business centre, free breakfast, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Avenida Palace
points_of_interest.description: It's in the emblematic Restauradores Square in a neoclassical building.

points_of_interest.name: Pestana Palace Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 192-room hotel in an old palace, with a wonderful garden and luxury spa.

points_of_interest.name: Goodnight Backpackers Hostel
points_of_interest.description: The interior design looks a bit like IKEA show-room, the staff know where the good places to go out dancing and drinking are and the location works for a budget traveler.

points_of_interest.name: Vila Galé Ópera
points_of_interest.description: Four-star, 259-room hotel next to the Tagus River. Adjoins Lisbon’s Congress Centre and the lively nightlife of Lisbon’s Docas area.

points_of_interest.name: Pensão Norte
points_of_interest.description: B&B style pension with friendly and accommodating staff in a quiet area.

points_of_interest.name: Rossio Hostel
points_of_interest.description: Great location, great staff, great free cooked breakfast, great hostel. The hostel offers dorms and privates. Free internet, TV room, lounge.

points_of_interest.name: Travellers House
points_of_interest.description: Nice hostel with lots of extras. Friendly staff and easy to meet people with their nightly activities. Free WiFi, breakfast, coffee and tea, maps and city advice, lots of guide books to look at and a book exchange for travelers who are tired of reading the same book over and over again.

points_of_interest.name: Alfama Patio Apartments
points_of_interest.description: formerly Alfama Patio Hostel Two-star out-of-the-way lodging (but it's directly on the Tram line 28). Full amenities from fast Wi-Fi to free crepe breakfast only compliment the fun staff, who sometimes even go out with you at night.

points_of_interest.name: Yes Hostel
points_of_interest.description: Relaxed and comfortable hostel with an excellent location. One of the largest hostels in Lisbon; opened in July 2009. Comfortable beds in large dorms, key operated lockers, free computer access as well as WiFi in every room, free breakfast, complimentary coffee and tea, 24 hour bar, access to their professional kitchen. Very friendly and accommodating staff. 3-course Portuguese dinners for €8 by their in-house chef.

points_of_interest.name: Ibis Lisboa Centro Saldanha Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Two-star, 116-room hotel. Travelers give this Ibis so-so reviews noting on the plus side the location only 5 min walk to the metro, and a good breakfast and on the minus side small rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Johnies Place Hostel
points_of_interest.description: Cosy hostel. No extra costs for Wi-Fi, printing, breakfast (for private rooms).

points_of_interest.name: Lisbon Story Guesthouse
points_of_interest.description: Cozy three-star, 11-room guesthouse with welcoming common areas and well-decorated small rooms at a budget price.

points_of_interest.name: The One Palácio da Anunciada
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 83-room hotel in a 16th-century palace with contemporary guest rooms. The old noble rooms now serve as dining areas. Guests can enjoy {{m2|2500}} of gardens, two swimming pools, spa, fitness centre, meeting rooms, business centre, and free Wi-Fi.
points_of_interest.address: Rua das Portas de Santo Antão 112-134

points_of_interest.name: Torel Palace Lisbon
points_of_interest.description: The four-star, 31-room Torel Palace is a boutique hotel on top of Sant'ana hill. From the carefully renovated two palaces and the outside gardens, terraces and the pool, visitors enjoy a stunning view over the city. Named after Portuguese Queens and Kings, each of the rooms is unique and offers an elegant home. Owned by a Portuguese and two Austrians. Offers breakfast all day long.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Travel Park Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Three-star, 61-room hotel that sits in the heart of Av. Almirante Reis. Just five minutes away from Lisbon International Airport and with underground station at doorstep.

points_of_interest.name: Lisbon Old Town Hostel
points_of_interest.description: A hostel, opened in 2007, catering to the young hip crowd with event listings on their website, free computer and internet access in the lobby and WiFi throughout the hostel.

points_of_interest.name: Poets Hostel
points_of_interest.description: The building is next the Chiado exit of the Baixa-Chiado metro station. Very helpful staff, clean rooms, dinners and activities are organized by the hostel. Big common room with TV and free internet. Dorms and privates available.

points_of_interest.name: InSuites Chiado Apartments I
points_of_interest.description: In the center of the Chiado, these apartments have 1 and 2 bedrooms.

points_of_interest.name: InSuites Chiado Apartments II
points_of_interest.description: Luxury apartments in the historical Chiado, Lisbon center, with 3 bedrooms.

points_of_interest.name: Bed&Breakfast Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Good rooms in a very central bed-and-breakfast with views all over Lisbon and the river.

points_of_interest.name: Camões
points_of_interest.description: Basic, clean and affordable.

points_of_interest.name: Oasis Backpackers' Mansion
points_of_interest.description: Backpackers rave about this hotel, often noting the friendly staff, large clean rooms, fun atmosphere and great dinners. It is a great place for a budget traveler to meet up with other travelers and feel safe when they go to bed at night - if they go to bed.

points_of_interest.name: Pensão Alegria
points_of_interest.description: Small cosy pension on a beautiful small square.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Portuense
points_of_interest.description: formerly Pensão Residencial Portuense
points_of_interest.address: Rua das Portas de Santo Antão 149-157

points_of_interest.name: Lisboa Central Hostel
points_of_interest.description: A fun, fresh and friendly place to stay in the heart of city in Marques de Pombal and Avenida da Liberdade. This international hostel provides a good base for sight-seeing by day and partying by night. All of Lisbon’s major night spots are easily accessible on foot.

points_of_interest.name: Residencial Vila Nova
points_of_interest.description: Vila Nova Guest House Two-star, 30-room, modern guest house close to Marques de Pombal station.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Borges Chiado
points_of_interest.description: Three-star, 100-room hotel. Spacious rooms with satellite TV. Very central, but somewhat expensive for the service.

points_of_interest.name: NH Collection Lisboa Liberdade
points_of_interest.description: Nice four-star, 108-room hotel in the center of the city. Seasonal rooftop pool, lawned terrace, bar, free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Inn Express Lisbon - Av. Liberdade
points_of_interest.description: Three-star, 108-room modern hotel with compact but efficient rooms, with kettle and mini-fridge. Near Avenida da Liberdade and the view from Parque Eduardo VII, and within walking distance of the old town. Nearby shops and restaurants are less crowded with tourists than those further south. Two metro lines give access to most areas of the city, and frequent bus 727 runs directly to the Belém museum district. Price includes breakfast and reliable wireless Internet access.

points_of_interest.name: Olissippo Lapa Palace
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 109-room hotel, property of Orient-Express Hotels, Trains & Cruises. A luxury palace hotel in one of Lisbon's seven hills, with gardens and pools, heated all year long. Member of the Leading Hotels of the World. With one of the best spas in Lisbon, gourmet food (its restaurant is considered by the Zagat Guide as one of the best in Lisbon) and one of best concierge services in the country.

points_of_interest.name: Eurostars das Letras
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 107-room modern hotel in the central Rato district. The hotel offers free wireless internet for guests along with two laptops with internet access.

points_of_interest.name: Sofitel Lisbon Liberdade
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 163-room hotel. Perhaps not particularly outstanding in standards or appointments among other Sofitels in Europe (meaning though that the standards are very high), the Lisbon Sofitel boasts a very central location on the Avenida da Liberdade, smack right at the entrance to the namesake metro station.
points_of_interest.address: Avenida Da Liberdade 129, 1250-207 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

points_of_interest.name: Tivoli Avenida Liberdade Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: The five-star, 285-room flagship of the Portuguese Tivoli hotel chain is most known for its rooftop terrace bar with splendid views.

points_of_interest.name: Altis Grand Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Five-star, 295 room hotel with swimming pool, spa, gym, business centre, conference facilities, bar, and free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Fontecruz Lisboa
points_of_interest.description: Autograph Collection Striking postmodern architecture and interior appointments are on the menu throughout this Marriott's luxury, five-star, 72-room boutique hotel.

pois.name: Igreja do Carmo
pois.description: The hilltop church of the former convent of Carmo is a towering memorial of the 1755 earthquake, which made the roof of the church collapse, but the Gothic arches of the nave survived. The church was preserved that way and now serves as the '''Museu Arqueológico''' in the extant parts of the building. The museum houses a hodgepodge of archaeological artifacts from around Portugal and the world including mummies from South America, tombs of Portuguese rulers, and the Stations of the Cross on 18th-century painted tiles. The assorted artifacts are not well explained, but the church is a sight to see and visitors come to relax in the grassy nave of the church, and draw or photograph the spires.
pois.hours: Oct-May: M-Sa 10:00-18:00; Jun-Sep: M-Sa 10:00-19:00; closed Su, 1 Jan, 1 May, 25 Dec

pois.name: Castelo de São Jorge
pois.description: St. George's Castle Humans settled on this hill as early as the 8th century BCE, and the first fortifications date from the 1st century BCE. Before the Portuguese conquest in the 1147 Siege of Lisbon, the site was successively occupied by the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans, and Moors. Sights within the castle include the permanent exhibition of archaeological artefacts with an emphasis on the 11th- and 12th-century Moors, ruins of the former Royal Palace of Alcáçova, a garden with native forest species, and a camera obscura showing the city's sights. The castle offers great view over the city and the river. If you have the energy, get there by walking from downtown, going through the fantastic old neighbourhood of Alfama.

pois.name: Centro de Arte Moderna
pois.description: Modern Art Centre A museum dedicated to art since the 1950s, focusing on Portuguese artists and including other nationalities, notably British and Armenian. Part of the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation.
pois.hours: Daily 10:00 – 18:00, closed on Tuesdays, 10:00 – 21:00 on Saturdays

pois.name: Monument to the Discoveries
pois.description: Padrão dos Descobrimentos Climbing the monument gives you a spectacular view of Belém.
pois.address: Avenida De Brasília, 1300-598 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.name: Lisbon Cathedral
pois.description: Sé de Lisboa, Igreja de Santa Maria Maior Built in 1147, the cathedral has survived various earthquakes and has undergone restoration, renovation, and modification over the years. Its elements include Romanesque, Gothic, and Baroque styles. It has been a national monument since 1910.

pois.name: Mosteiro dos Jerónimos
pois.description: Jerónimos Monastery A {{UNESCO}}, the monastery was built in the 16th century and is an outstanding example of the Portuguese late Gothic Manueline style.
pois.hours: Oct-May: Tu-Su 10:00-17:30; May-Sep: Tu-Su 10:00-18:30; last entry 30 min before closing; closed 1 Jan, Easter, 1 May, 13 Jun, and 25 Dec

pois.name: Museu Nacional do Azulejo
pois.description: National Tile Museum One of the most important national museums, dedicated to Portuguese ''azulejo'' tiles since the late 1400s. It's in the former Madre de Deus Convent, founded in 1509 by Queen Leonor.

pois.name: Museu do Teatro Romano
pois.description: Roman Theatre Museum Along the way from downtown to Saint George's Castle.
pois.address: Rua de São Mamede, nº 3 A

pois.name: Aqueduto das Aguas Livres
pois.description: This is a historic aqueduct in the city of Lisbon, Portugal. It is one of the most remarkable examples of 18th-century Portuguese engineering, including the largest stone arch in the world. The main course of the aqueduct covers 18 km, but the whole network of canals extends through nearly 58 km. This reservoir, with a capacity of 5,500 m³ of water, was designed by Carlos Mardel. It is now deactivated and can be visited as part of the Museu da Água (Water Museum).

Excellent panorama of the river and surroundings. No elevator.
pois.hours: Tu-Su 10:00-17:00, platform 10:00-18:00 (closed Mondays, shorter hours in winter)

pois.name: Statue to Afonso de Albuquerque
pois.description: In front of the former Royal Palace of Belém, now the Presidential Palace, there is a massive statue looking out to sea, representing Afonso de Albuquerque, second ruler of Portuguese India in the early 16th century.
pois.address: Praça Afonso De Albuquerque 15, 1300-995 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.description:
The Torre de Belém is a 16th-century fortification in Lisbon that showcases Portugal's maritime power. 
It features a mix of architectural styles, including Manueline and Moorish influences. 
The tower is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a symbol of Europe's Age of Discoveries.
pois.hours: Oct-May: Tu-Su 10:00-17:30; May-Sep: Tu-Su 10:00-18:30; last entry 30 min before closing; closed 1 Jan, Easter, 1 May, 13 Jun, and 25 Dec

pois.name: Monsanto Forest Park
pois.description: Parque Florestal de Monsanto A municipal protected forest, the largest green patch in the city, covering almost 10 km². It offers a well-diversified, tree-covered area. 50 ha is set aside as the Ecological Park, which runs an interpretation centre, with space for permanent and occasional exhibitions, and a Centre of Multimedia Resources.
pois.address: Pista Cruz Das Oliveiras, 1500-389 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.name: Ajuda Botanical Gardens
pois.description: Jardim Botânico da Ajuda The botanical garden of Ajuda is one of the oldest gardens in Europe and is considered the first in Portugal. After the earthquake that occurred in 1755, the homeless Portuguese royal family decided to build a new royal residence at Ajuda but also gardens around it. This 10-acre garden was laid out in from 1858-1873.

pois.name: Centro de Arte Moderna
pois.description: Modern Art Centre A museum dedicated to art since the 1950s, focusing on Portuguese artists and including other nationalities, notably British and Armenian. Part of the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation.
pois.hours: Daily 10:00 – 18:00, closed on Tuesdays, 10:00 – 21:00 on Saturdays

pois.name: Calouste Gulbenkian Museum
pois.description: One of the best museums in Lisbon. Created from the personal collection of the art and artifact collector Calouste Gulbenkian. The collection include Egyptian artefacts; Islamic and oriental art; paintings by masters such as Rembrandt, Manet, Monet, Renoir, and Cassat; and a large collection of objects made by the Art Nouveau jeweler René Lalique. Gulbenkian was an Armenian born in the Ottoman Empire who, through his investments in Iraqi oil, became one of the wealthiest men of his time. During a journey he fell ill and had to seek medical attention in Lisbon. He fell in love with the city and decided live out his final days there. After his death his immense collections were organized into this museum. The ''[https://gulbenkian.pt/jardim/en/ Gulbenkian Gardens]'' which surround the museums and foundation building are worth a visit in and of themselves, as a little oasis in the middle of downtown Lisbon. They're free and open sunrise to sunset.

pois.name: Castelo de São Jorge
pois.description: St. George's Castle Humans settled on this hill as early as the 8th century BCE, and the first fortifications date from the 1st century BCE. Before the Portuguese conquest in the 1147 Siege of Lisbon, the site was successively occupied by the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans, and Moors. Sights within the castle include the permanent exhibition of archaeological artefacts with an emphasis on the 11th- and 12th-century Moors, ruins of the former Royal Palace of Alcáçova, a garden with native forest species, and a camera obscura showing the city's sights. The castle offers great view over the city and the river. If you have the energy, get there by walking from downtown, going through the fantastic old neighbourhood of Alfama.

pois.description: Jerónimos Monastery A {{UNESCO}}, the monastery was built in the 16th century and is an outstanding example of the Portuguese late Gothic Manueline style.

pois.name: Ponte 25 de Abril
pois.description: This sister bridge of the San Francisco – Oakland Bay Bridge was designed by the same architect in 1966 to connect Lisbon with the Setubal peninsula across the Tagus (Tejo) River. Formerly known as the Salazar Bridge, it was renamed after the Carnation Revolution which, on 25 April 1974, ended the dictatorship.

pois.name: Torre de Belém
pois.description:
The Torre de Belém is a 16th-century fortification in Lisbon that showcases Portugal's maritime power. 
It features a mix of architectural styles, including Manueline and Moorish influences. 
The tower is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a symbol of Europe's Age of Discoveries.
pois.hours: Oct-May: Tu-Su 10:00-17:30; May-Sep: Tu-Su 10:00-18:30; last entry 30 min before closing; closed 1 Jan, Easter, 1 May, 13 Jun, and 25 Dec

pois.name: Castelo de São Jorge
pois.description: St. George's Castle Humans settled on this hill as early as the 8th century BCE, and the first fortifications date from the 1st century BCE. Before the Portuguese conquest in the 1147 Siege of Lisbon, the site was successively occupied by the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans, and Moors. Sights within the castle include the permanent exhibition of archaeological artefacts with an emphasis on the 11th- and 12th-century Moors, ruins of the former Royal Palace of Alcáçova, a garden with native forest species, and a camera obscura showing the city's sights. The castle offers great view over the city and the river. If you have the energy, get there by walking from downtown, going through the fantastic old neighbourhood of Alfama.

pois.description: Padrão dos Descobrimentos Climbing the monument gives you a spectacular view of Belém.

pois.name: Pastéis de Belém
pois.description: Antiga Confeitaria de Belém The most famous of pastelarias, and justly so. They are served right out of the oven there, with the side of confectioner's sugar and cinnamon. As you navigate through the tile-covered labyrinthine passages of the expansive shop, stop to look at the workers behind glass panels turning the endless stream of these delicacies, just baked, each in its own little ramekin, over onto the waiting trays. These are absolutely a must-eat and you can't possibly regret it.

pois.name: Lux Fragil
pois.description: It's in a former warehouse and part owned by American actor John Malkovich.
pois.address: Av. Infante D. Henrique, Armazém A

pois.name: Praça do Comércio
pois.description: This magnificent plaza, facing the river, is the beginning of Lisboa's downtown. It is also known as 'Terreiro do Paço', meaning 'Grounds of the Palace', relating to its function before the Great Earthquake of 1755. The upper floors of the yellow buildings surrounding the square are mainly used as government offices, while the lower floors often contains cafés and restaurants. King Josef I, who ruled during the reconstruction of Lisbon, is seen as a mounted statue in the middle of the square, while the arch facing north is a tribute to the explorer Vasco da Gama.
pois.address: Praça Do Comércio 72, 1100-148 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.name: Museu Nacional do Azulejo

pois.name: Calouste Gulbenkian Museum
pois.description: One of the best museums in Lisbon. Created from the personal collection of the art and artifact collector Calouste Gulbenkian. The collection include Egyptian artefacts; Islamic and oriental art; paintings by masters such as Rembrandt, Manet, Monet, Renoir, and Cassat; and a large collection of objects made by the Art Nouveau jeweler René Lalique. Gulbenkian was an Armenian born in the Ottoman Empire who, through his investments in Iraqi oil, became one of the wealthiest men of his time. During a journey he fell ill and had to seek medical attention in Lisbon. He fell in love with the city and decided live out his final days there. After his death his immense collections were organized into this museum. The ''[https://gulbenkian.pt/jardim/en/ Gulbenkian Gardens]'' which surround the museums and foundation building are worth a visit in and of themselves, as a little oasis in the middle of downtown Lisbon. They're free and open sunrise to sunset.

pois.name: Museu Colecção Berardo
pois.description: The permanent collection of the museum consists of the Berardo Collection, which is made up of modern and contemporary art, with major art movements like abstract expressionism, Abstraction-Création, action painting, body Art, constructivism, cubism, De Stijl, digital art, experimental art, geometric abstraction, kinetic art, minimal art, neo-expressionism, neo-plasticism, neo-Realism, op art, photography, photorealism, pop art, realism, suprematism, surrealism. Includes artists like Piet Mondrian, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Pablo Picasso and Jackson Pollock, and Francis Bacon.

pois.name: Museu Nacional dos Coches
pois.description: National Coach Museum Housed in the former riding school of the palace, don't miss the world's largest collection of horse-drawn coaches and other royal vehicles. One of Lisbon's many unusual museums. In the "Museum street", Belem.

pois.name: Igreja do Carmo
pois.description: The hilltop church of the former convent of Carmo is a towering memorial of the 1755 earthquake, which made the roof of the church collapse, but the Gothic arches of the nave survived. The church was preserved that way and now serves as the '''Museu Arqueológico''' in the extant parts of the building. The museum houses a hodgepodge of archaeological artifacts from around Portugal and the world including mummies from South America, tombs of Portuguese rulers, and the Stations of the Cross on 18th-century painted tiles. The assorted artifacts are not well explained, but the church is a sight to see and visitors come to relax in the grassy nave of the church, and draw or photograph the spires.
pois.hours: Oct-May: M-Sa 10:00-18:00; Jun-Sep: M-Sa 10:00-19:00; closed Su, 1 Jan, 1 May, 25 Dec

pois.name: MUDE – Museu do Design e da Moda
pois.description: Museum of Design and Fashion The collection has about 1,000 items of furniture and accessories and over 1,200 pieces of haute couture clothing.
pois.hours: Temporarily closed for renovations; planned reopening 2023

pois.name: Miradouro de Santa Luzia
pois.description: Good viewpoint in Alfama uphill from the cathedral along tram route. Lovely view over rooftops and river.

pois.name: Ajuda Botanical Gardens
pois.description: Jardim Botânico da Ajuda The botanical garden of Ajuda is one of the oldest gardens in Europe and is considered the first in Portugal. After the earthquake that occurred in 1755, the homeless Portuguese royal family decided to build a new royal residence at Ajuda but also gardens around it. This 10-acre garden was laid out in from 1858-1873.

pois.name: Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara
pois.description:
Jardim de São Pedro de Alcântara offers a stunning panorama from its lovely garden. Located on top of the Elevador da Glória, it provides breathtaking views. 

This picturesque spot is situated near the northern corner of Bairro Alto, making it a great place to take in the sights.

pois.name: Centro Cultural de Belém
pois.description: CCB, Belém Cultural Center CCB is a {{m2|140000}} complex of artistic and cultural venues. It has spaces for meetings and conferences, performing arts (film, opera, ballet, theatre, and music), and art exhibits (art, architecture, design, and photography).

pois.name: Centro de Arte Moderna
pois.description: Modern Art Centre A museum dedicated to art since the 1950s, focusing on Portuguese artists and including other nationalities, notably British and Armenian. Part of the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation.
pois.hours: Daily 10:00 – 18:00, closed on Tuesdays, 10:00 – 21:00 on Saturdays

pois.name: Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga
pois.description: Portugal's impressive national art collection, including 14-19th century European painting, artefacts of Portuguese contact with the East and Africa and a collection of ecclesiastical treasures. Highlights include Dürer's St Jerome, Hieronymus Bosch's Temptations of St Antony, Nuno Gonçalves' Adoration of St Vincent, and 16th century Japanese paintings of Portuguese traders.

pois.name: Monument to the Discoveries
pois.description: Padrão dos Descobrimentos Climbing the monument gives you a spectacular view of Belém.
pois.address: Avenida De Brasília, 1300-598 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.name: Jardim Zoológico
pois.description:
Jardim Zoológico is a popular zoo featuring a variety of animals in naturalistic enclosures. 
With thousands of zoos worldwide, it stands out as a must-visit destination, attracting millions of visitors each year.

pois.name: Museu da Marioneta
pois.description: Puppetry Museum The museum covers the history of puppetry around the world, with an emphasis on Portugal. Various types of puppets are on display.
pois.address: Convento das Bernardas, Rua da Esperança 146

pois.name: Lisbon Cathedral
pois.description: Sé de Lisboa, Igreja de Santa Maria Maior Built in 1147, the cathedral has survived various earthquakes and has undergone restoration, renovation, and modification over the years. Its elements include Romanesque, Gothic, and Baroque styles. It has been a national monument since 1910.

pois.description: Jerónimos Monastery A {{UNESCO}}, the monastery was built in the 16th century and is an outstanding example of the Portuguese late Gothic Manueline style.

pois.name: Basílica da Estrela
pois.description: This Neoclassical and Baroque basilica, dedicated to the Sacred Heart of Jesus, was built in the late 1700s by Queen Maria I in fulfilment of a vow. The Queen is entombed in the right transept. Among the artworks is a nativity scene made up of over 500 cork and terracotta figures by Joaquim Machado de Castro.

pois.description: MAAT – Museu de Arte, Arquitetura e Tecnologia This museum of contemporary art is housed in a riverside building of contemporary design.
pois.hours: W–M 11:00–19:00 (Jun–Sep: F Sa until 22:00), closed Tu

pois.name: Praça Marquês de Pombal
pois.description: Essentially a large roundabout with a sizeable statue of a former Portuguese prime minister in the middle.
pois.address: Túnel Do Marquês, 1250-161 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.name: Museu Nacional do Azulejo
pois.description: National Tile Museum One of the most important national museums, dedicated to Portuguese ''azulejo'' tiles since the late 1400s. It's in the former Madre de Deus Convent, founded in 1509 by Queen Leonor.

pois.name: Museu Colecção Berardo
pois.description: The permanent collection of the museum consists of the Berardo Collection, which is made up of modern and contemporary art, with major art movements like abstract expressionism, Abstraction-Création, action painting, body Art, constructivism, cubism, De Stijl, digital art, experimental art, geometric abstraction, kinetic art, minimal art, neo-expressionism, neo-plasticism, neo-Realism, op art, photography, photorealism, pop art, realism, suprematism, surrealism. Includes artists like Piet Mondrian, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Pablo Picasso and Jackson Pollock, and Francis Bacon.

pois.name: Museu Militar de Lisboa
pois.description: Lisbon Military Museum Housed in a 16th-century foundry, this museum holds its testaments to Portuguese military history, and contains many artifacts, including a sword used by Vasco da Gama.

pois.name: Museu da Marinha
pois.description: Navy Museum One of the most important in Europe, evoking Portugal's domination of the seas. Its colossal 17,000 items are installed in the west wing of Jerónimos Monastery, and include model ships from the Age of Discovery onward. The oldest exhibit is a wooden figure representing the Archangel Raphael that accompanied Vasco da Gama on his voyage to India.

pois.name: Cemitério dos Prazeres
pois.description: This large cemetery is packed with majestic gravestones and mausoleums, separated by wide, pedestrian, tree-lined "streets". Many graves are marked with icons telling something about the person's role in historical Lisbon. A beautiful respite from the busy city.

pois.name: Museu Nacional dos Coches
pois.description: National Coach Museum Housed in the former riding school of the palace, don't miss the world's largest collection of horse-drawn coaches and other royal vehicles. One of Lisbon's many unusual museums. In the "Museum street", Belem.

pois.name: Fundação Arpad Szenes / Vieira da Silva
pois.description: This museum is installed in the restored 18th-century former Royal Silk Factory. Its permanent collection covers a wide time period of the works of 20th-century painters Arpad Szenes and Maria Helena Vieira da Silva, and regularly hosts exhibits by their contemporaries.

pois.name: Museu do Teatro Romano
pois.description: Roman Theatre Museum Along the way from downtown to Saint George's Castle.
pois.address: Rua de São Mamede, nº 3 A

pois.name: Planetário Calouste Gulbenkian
pois.description: Calouste Gulbenkian Planetarium The planetarium has 32 star projectors, capable of presenting more than 9,000 stars. It holds a chunk of moon rock given by U.S. President Richard Nixon.
pois.hours: Temporarily closed for renovations; planned reopening Oct 2021

pois.name: Aqueduto das Aguas Livres
pois.description: This is a historic aqueduct in the city of Lisbon, Portugal. It is one of the most remarkable examples of 18th-century Portuguese engineering, including the largest stone arch in the world. The main course of the aqueduct covers 18 km, but the whole network of canals extends through nearly 58 km. The Mãe d'Água (Mother of the Water) reservoir of the Amoreiras, the largest of the water reservoirs, was finished in 1834. This reservoir, with a capacity of 5,500 m³ of water, was designed by Carlos Mardel. It is now deactivated and can be visited as part of the Museu da Água (Water Museum).
pois.address: Rua Gorgel Do Amaral 4, 1250-259 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.name: Panteão Nacional
pois.description: Igreja do Santa Engrácia This is one of the most striking buildings in Lisbon. Its tall dome and white facade makes it a real landmark in Alfama/Eastern Lisbon. Excellent views from the rooftop terrace. Construction began in 1681, then halted until the dome was added in 1966 and then converted to the National Pantheon. Amália Rodrigues, queen of fado, is buried here, and fresh roses can be seen on the tomb. The church also has wide viewing platform on the rooftop all around its dome. Excellent panorama of the river and surroundings. No elevator.
pois.hours: Tu-Su 10:00-17:00, platform 10:00-18:00 (closed Mondays, shorter hours in winter)

pois.name: Ponte 25 de Abril
pois.description: This sister bridge of the San Francisco – Oakland Bay Bridge was designed by the same architect in 1966 to connect Lisbon with the Setubal peninsula across the Tagus (Tejo) River. Formerly known as the Salazar Bridge, it was renamed after the Carnation Revolution which, on 25 April 1974, ended the dictatorship.

pois.name: Espaço Novo Banco
pois.description:
The Espaço Novo Banco is located in a historic building that dates back to the Estado Novo era, a time of significant cultural and economic change in Portugal. 
Today, visitors can explore the Espaço Novo Banco and learn about this fascinating period in Portuguese history.

pois.name: Statue to Afonso de Albuquerque
pois.description: In front of the former Royal Palace of Belém, now the Presidential Palace, there is a massive statue looking out to sea, representing Afonso de Albuquerque, second ruler of Portuguese India in the early 16th century.
pois.address: Praça Afonso De Albuquerque 15, 1300-995 Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

pois.name: Lisbon Botanical Gardens
pois.description: Jardim Botânico A hidden gem. It was created several hundred years ago, by a King of Portugal at the time of the Discoveries. The story goes that this King wanted one of every type of plant in the world, and although that's unlikely, there is a huge collection dating back by three or four centuries which is worth checking out. And there's something quite eerie about seeing plants or huge trees from completely different climates growing next to each other in apparent harmony. A great place to take a picnic: this green oasis is completely surrounded by city but even the city sounds filter out.
